questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the clinic with symptoms including fever, cough, runny nose, sensitivity to light, and a sore throat. The physical examination reveals a rash that began on the head and subsequently spread to cover the entire body. The rash is characterized by large, flat, red spots that have coalesced. Based on the clinical presentation described, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Measles

 

Option C:

 

The clinical features described in the case are typical of Measles or Rubeola.

  • Measles is a highly contagious viral infection that is common in children.
  • The symptoms typically start with a fever, cough, runny nose, and red, watery eyes.
  • After a few days, a rash develops, which starts on the head and then spreads to the rest of the body.
  • The rash consists of larger, flat, red spots that may merge together.
  • The child may also complain of sensitivity to light and a sore throat.

 

Explanation:

 

 Option A: Varicella or Chickenpox, is a viral infection that typically presents with a rash consisting of small, itchy, fluid-filled blisters. The rash starts on the face and then spreads to the rest of the body.

 

Option B: Rubella or German measles, is a viral infection that can cause a rash, fever, and other symptoms. However, the rash in rubella typically starts on the face and then spreads to the rest of the body. The rash consists of smaller, pink or light red spots that may merge together.

 

Option D: Scarlet fever, is a bacterial infection that can cause a rash, fever, and other symptoms. The rash consists of small, red bumps that feel like sandpaper and appear on the chest and stomach first, then spread to other areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of fever, cough, runny nose (the three "C's": cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis), along with a rash that starts on the head and spreads to the rest of the body, sensitivity to light (photophobia), and a sore throat, is highly indicative of Measles (Rubeola).

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-1542-1547.

questions.text: A mother consults for her 5-year-old child who has developed multiple small, raised, pink or skin-colored bumps on the skin. These bumps are described as painless, smooth, round or dome-shaped with a dimpled center, and may exhibit a waxy or pearly appearance. The child is otherwise in good health with no additional symptoms. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of molluscum contagiosum is made. Which of the following statements are true regarding the features of molluscum contagiosum?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Henderson Patterson bodies are seen in the histopathological examination: This is true. Henderson-Patterson bodies, also known as molluscum bodies, are characteristic cytoplasmic inclusion bodies found in the epidermal cells infected with the molluscum contagiosum virus, visible upon histopathological examination.

 

Option B: Immunocompromised patients are most commonly affected: While molluscum contagiosum is common in children and can occur in any individual, it is more persistent, widespread, and sometimes more challenging to treat in immunocompromised patients, making them a notably affected group.

 

Option C: The causative organism is a brick-shaped virus: Molluscum contagiosum is caused by a member of the Poxviridae family, which are large, complex viruses, and typically described as "brick-shaped" due to its rectangular shape.

 

Educational Objective:

Molluscum contagiosum, a common viral skin infection, especially in pediatric populations. The characteristic Henderson-Patterson bodies found upon histopathological examination, the increased prevalence and severity in immunocompromised patients, and the nature of the causative poxvirus, provides comprehensive insight into the disease, aiding in accurate diagnosis and management.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-1580-1581

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is presented to a pediatric clinic by their mother with a history of a recent viral infection, which was shortly followed by the sudden onset of petechiae and purpura. During the clinical evaluation, the physician notes that the petechiae are non-palpable and there is mild splenomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal a white blood cell count of 13,000/mm3 and a platelet count of 78,000/mm3. C-reactive protein (CRP) is also found to be elevated. Which of the following findings, if present, would most likely exclude a diagnosis of Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of splenomegaly

 

Option B:

 

The presence of splenomegaly is not typical for ITP, which is characterized by isolated low platelet counts with otherwise normal examination and laboratory findings. ITP, also known as immune thrombocytopenia, is a condition where the immune system attacks and destroys platelets, leading to a low platelet count, but it does not usually cause spleen enlargement. Therefore, the presence of splenomegaly may suggest another underlying condition and would lead a clinician to consider alternative diagnoses.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Decreased Platelet count: Thrombocytopenia is a hallmark of ITP, can be a response to infection or stress, not necessarily ruling out ITP.

 

Option C. Non-palpable petechiae: Non-palpable petechiae are consistent with a diagnosis of ITP, as they are a common clinical feature of thrombocytopenia.

 

Option D. Elevation of CRP: CRP can be elevated in many conditions, including ITP, as it is an acute-phase reactant and can indicate inflammation or infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of ITP, typically includes isolated thrombocytopenia without other significant physical findings such as splenomegaly. Recognizing that splenomegaly is not a characteristic feature of ITP is important for the differential diagnosis of thrombocytopenia.

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition page 3800

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to a clinic by her mother due to concerns about the child's failure to thrive and persistent fatigue. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes severe anemia, splenomegaly, and jaundice. The mother mentions a vague family history of a "blood problem" but lacks specific details. Due to the complexity of the case, the child is referred to a hematologist for a more thorough evaluation. Hemoglobin electrophoresis results come back normal, but the CBC shows normocytic anemia, and the peripheral smear reveals the presence of bizarre erythrocytes, including spiculated cells. These findings suggest that the child's anemia may be due to an enzyme deficiency. Given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, what is the most common enzyme deficiency that could result in this type of anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pyruvate kinase deficiency

 

Option D:

 

Pyruvate kinase deficiency (PKD) is an erythrocyte enzymopathy involving the glycolytic pathway. Erythrocytes have evolved without oxidative phosphorylation to form adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the compound essential for providing the erythrocyte energy.

 

Clinical features:

 

Mild form of PKD; May appear to have no symptoms at all.

 

Severe form of PKD Symptoms include:

 

  • Chills Fatigue
  • Earlier in life symptoms tend to be detected
  • Pallor, dark urine and enlarged spleen

 

Biochemical findings of hemolyticanemia;

  • Elevated indirect bilirubin levels
  • Elevated Hapatoglobin
  • Elevated total reticulocyte count
  • Elevated serum LDH

 

Diagnosis of PKD

  1. Measuring the amount of pyruvate kinase in red blood cells
  2. If there is a family history, mutation analysis could be done to determine carrier status of an individual

 

Medical care and Treatment

  • In the severe cases
  • Multiple blood transfusions may be required
  • Splenectomy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency: This is the most common enzyme deficiency worldwide, leading to hemolytic anemia often triggered by certain foods, drugs, or infections. However, the peripheral smear typically shows "bite cells" and "blister cells," not the bizarre erythrocytes as described.

 

Option B. Glucose-6-Phosphatase: Deficiency in this enzyme is associated with glycogen storage diseases, particularly von Gierke disease, and not typically with hemolyticanemia.

 

Option C. Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC): Deficiency affects the ability to convert pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, leading to neurological deficits and lactic acidosis, rather than hemolyticanemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyruvate kinase deficiency is a cause of normocytic anemia with bizarre erythrocytes on peripheral smear, leading to symptoms of anemia, splenomegaly, and jaundice. This condition should be distinguished from other enzyme deficiencies like G6PD deficiency, which presents differently on peripheral blood smears.

 

Ref; Nelson 21st edition, Chapter 490 – Page  No 10062-10065

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is evaluated for intellectual disability, a mongoloid slant of the eyes, sandal gap toes, and distinctive facial features indicative of a certain genetic condition. Given these clinical signs, which type of myeloid lineage leukemia is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (M7)

 

Option A:

 

The clinical features are suggestive of Downs syndrome (trisomy 21).

 

The most common leukemia in case of down syndrome is ALL, but most common myeloid origin leukemia is Acute megakaryoblasticleukemia, which is AML M7.

 

Leukemias based on FAB classification are,

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Acute erythroid leukemia: This subtype, involving the proliferation of erythroid precursors, is less common in the general population and not specifically associated with Down syndrome.

 

Option C: Acute monocytic leukemia: While this subtype (M5 under the FAB classification) involves the proliferation of monocyte precursors, it is not the most common in children with Down syndrome.

 

Option D: Acute myelomonocytic leukemia: This subtype (M4 under the FAB classification) involves both monocyte and granulocyte precursors but is not the most prevalent myeloid leukemia in Down syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children with Down syndrome have an increased incidence of leukemia, particularly Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) and Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML), with Acute MegakaryoblasticLeukemia (AMKL) being the most common AML subtype.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 610-615 and Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter-161, Page No-4832

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their mother due to pain and swelling below the ears and near the jawline, accompanied by fever and difficulty swallowing. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes swollen and tender salivary glands, leading to a diagnosis of Mumps. Given this diagnosis, which of the following is the most common complication of mumps in pediatric patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aseptic Meningitis

 

Option C:

 

The most common complication of Mumps in children is Aseptic Meningitis, where as in adults it results in Orchitis and Oophoritis.

 

  • The clinical features described in the case are typical of mumps.
  • Mumps is a viral infection that primarily affects the salivary glands, causing them to become swollen and painful.
  • The child may also have a fever and difficulty swallowing.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Orchitis: While orchitis, an inflammation of the testicles, is a recognized complication of mumps, it primarily affects post-pubertal males and is less common in pre-pubertal children.

 

Option B: Oophoritis: Oophoritis, or inflammation of the ovaries, can occur in females as a complication of mumps but is less frequent than aseptic meningitis.

 

Option D: SSPE: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare, progressive brain disorder related to measles infection, not mumps, and is therefore not relevant to this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mumps, a viral infection primarily affecting the parotid salivary glands, can also impact the central nervous system, leading to symptoms such as headache, fever, and neck stiffness indicative of meningitis. However, most cases of aseptic meningitis related to mumps are self-limiting and resolve without long-term sequelae.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-1552-1553.

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her 8-year-old child with complaints of fever, sore throat, and a rash. On asking history, the child explains that the rash started on the chest and then spread to the rest of the body. On examination the rash consisted of small, red bumps that felt like sandpaper. The child also complains of a headache, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, the tongue is found to be red and swollen, the image is given below.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Scarlet fever

 

Option C:

 

The clinical features described in the case are typical of scarlet fever.

  • Scarlet fever is a bacterial infection caused by group A Streptococcus bacteria that produces a toxin causing the characteristic rash and other symptoms.

  • The symptoms typically start with a sore throat, fever, and a bright red tongue (strawberry tongue). After a few days, a rash develops on the chest and then spreads to the rest of the body.

  • The rash consists of small, red bumps that feel like sandpaper and may itch.

  • The child may also complain of a headache, nausea, and vomiting.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Streptococcal pharyngitis, is a bacterial infection of the throat caused by group A streptococcus bacteria. It can cause a sore throat, fever, and other symptoms, but is not typically associated with a rash.

 

Option B: Rocky Mountain spotted fever, is a bacterial infection transmitted by ticks. It can cause fever, headache, and a characteristic spotted rash, but is not typically associated with a sore throat or the rash described in the case.

 

Option D: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, is a bacterial infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus that produces a toxin causing the skin to blister and peel. It typically presents with fever, a red, scalded-looking rash, and other symptoms, but is not typically associated with a sore throat or the rash described in the case.

 

Educational Objective:

The clinical presentation of fever, sore throat, rash starting on the chest and spreading, rash texture described as sandpaper-like, along with headache, nausea, vomiting, and a red, swollen tongue (often referred to as "strawberry tongue")is indicative of Scarlet fever.

 

Scarlet fever is a condition that arises as a result of an infection with group A Streptococcus, which produces a toxin leading to the characteristic rash.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-1328
